chapter.title: ⪪ Server Configuration
chapter.para: This chapter introduces the &yast; configuration module for the ⪪ server. You can set and configure mirroring credentials, ⪪ database passwords, and e-mail addresses to send SMT reports to. It also lets you set the ⪪ job schedule, and activate or deactivate the ⪪ service.
To configure ⪪ with ⪪ Server Configuration, follow these steps:

step.para: Start the &yast; module SMT Server Configuration from the &yast; control center or by running yast smt-server on the command line.

To activate ⪪, check the Enable Subscription Management Tool Service (SMT) option in the Customer Center Access tab. If you want to disable ⪪, uncheck this option. For more information about activating ⪪ with &yast;, see .
If the firewall is enabled, check Open Port in Firewall.

In the Customer Center Configuration section of the Customer Center Access tab, you can set the custom server URLs. Set and test credentials for the SUSE Update service. Correct credentials are necessary to enable mirroring from the download server and determine the products that should be mirrored. Also set the e-mail address used for the registration and the URL of your ⪪ server and your ⪪ server URL. For more information, see .
In the Database and Reporting tab, set the password for the ⪪ user in the MySQL database and enter the e-mail addresses where reports should be sent. For more information, see and .
In the Scheduled SMT Jobs tab, set a schedule of periodic ⪪ jobs, such as synchronization of updates, &scc; registration, and ⪪ report generation. For more information, see .
If you want to abort the configuration and cancel any changes, click Cancel.

note.para: When the ⪪ Configuration applies configuration changes, it checks for the existence of the common server certificate. If the certificate does not exist, you will be asked if the certificate should be created.

sect1.title: Activating and Deactivating ⪪ with &yast;
sect1.para: &yast; provides an easy way to activate or deactivate the ⪪ service. To activate ⪪ with &yast;, follow these steps:

step.para: Open the Customer Center Access tab of the ⪪ Configuration .
Check the Enable Subscription Management Tool service (SMT) option.

note.para: If not already configured, organization credentials should be configured before activating ⪪. For more information about how to set organization credentials with &yast;, see .

step.para: Click Finish to apply the changes and leave the ⪪ Configuration.

sect1.para: To deactivate ⪪ with &yast;, follow these steps:

step.para: Open the Customer Center Access tab of the ⪪ Configuration.
Uncheck the Enable Subscription Management Tool service (SMT) option.
Click Finish to apply the changes and leave the ⪪ Configuration.

sect1.para: When activating ⪪, the following important operations are performed by &yast;:

listitem.para: The Apache configuration is changed by creating symbolic links in the /etc/apache2/conf.d/ directory. Links to the /etc/smt.d/nu_server.conf and /etc/smt.d/smt_mod_perl.conf files are created there.
The Apache Web server is started (or reloaded if already running).
The MariaDB server is started (or reloaded if already running). The smt user and all necessary tables in the database are created as needed.
The schema of the ⪪ database is checked. If the database schema is outdated, the ⪪ database is upgraded to conform to the current schema.
Cron is adjusted by creating a symbolic link in the /etc/cron.d/ directory. A link to the /etc/smt.d/novell.com-smt file is created there.

sect1.para: When deactivating ⪪, the following important operations are performed by &yast;:

listitem.para: Symbolic links created upon ⪪ activation in the /etc/apache2/conf.d/ and /etc/cron.d/ directories are deleted.
The Cron daemon, the Apache server and the MySQL database daemon are reloaded. Neither Apache nor MySQL are stopped, because they may be used for other purposes than the ⪪ service.

sect1.title: Setting the Update Server Credentials with &yast;
sect1.para: &yast; provides an interface to set and test the download server credentials and the URL of the download server service. To do so, follow these steps:

figure.title: Setting the Update Server Credentials with &yast;

step.para: Open the Customer Center Access tab of the ⪪ Configuration. If the credentials have been already set with &yast; or the /etc/smt.conf configuration file, they appear in the dialog. Otherwise, the User and Password fields are blank.
If you do not have your credentials, visit &scc; to obtain them. For more details, see .
Enter your user name in User and the corresponding password in Password.

Click Test to check the credentials. &yast; will try to download a list of available repositories with the provided
credentials. If the test succeeds, the last line of the test results will read Test result: success. If the test fails, check the provided
credentials and try again.

figure.title: Successful Test of the Update Server Credentials

step.para: Enter the SCC E-mail Used for Registration. This should be the address you used to register to &scc;.
Enter Your SMT Server URL if it has not been detected automatically.
Click OK or continue with other configurations.

sect1.title: Setting ⪪ Database Password with &yast;
sect1.para: For security reasons, ⪪ uses its own user in the database. &yast; provides an interface for setting up or changing the ⪪ database password. To set or change the ⪪ database password with &yast;, follow these steps:

step.para: Open the Database and Reporting tab of the ⪪ Configuration module.
Enter the ⪪ Database Password for ⪪ User. Confirm the password by reentering it and click OK, or continue with other configurations.

sect1.title: Setting E-mail Addresses to Receive Reports with &yast;
sect1.para: &yast; ⪪ provides an interface for setting up a list of e-mail addresses to which ⪪ reports will be sent. To edit this list of addresses, follow these steps:

step.para: Open the Database and Reporting tab of the ⪪ Configuration.
The list of e-mail addresses is shown in the table. You can Add, Edit, or Delete addresses with the relevant buttons.
Click OK or continue with other configurations.

sect1.para: The comma-separated list of addresses for ⪪ reports is written to the reportEmail option of the /etc/smt.conf configuration file.

sect1.title: Setting the ⪪ Job Schedule with &yast;
sect1.para: The ⪪ Configuration module provides an interface to schedule periodical ⪪ jobs. &yast; uses cron to schedule configured jobs. If needed, cron can be used directly. Five types of periodical jobs can be set:

listitem.para: Synchronizes with &scc;, updates repositories, and downloads new updates.
Generates and sends ⪪ Subscription Reports to addresses defined in .
Registers all clients to &scc; that are not already registered or that changed their data since the last registration.
Cleans up queued jobs. It will remove finished or failed jobs from the job queue that are older than 8 days and remove job artifacts that remained in the database as result of an error.

sect1.para: To configure the schedule of ⪪ jobs with &yast;, follow these steps:

step.para: Open the Scheduled SMT Jobs tab of the ⪪ Configuration. The table contains a list of all scheduled jobs, their type, frequency, date, and time to run. You can add, delete or edit these scheduled events.
If you want to add a scheduled ⪪ job, click Add. The Adding New SMT Scheduled Job dialog opens.
Choose the synchronization job to schedule. You can choose between Synchronization of Updates, Report Generation, SCC Registration, and Job Queue Cleanup.
Choose the Frequency of the new scheduled ⪪ job. Jobs can be performed Daily, Weekly, Monthly, or Periodically (every n-th hour or every m-th minute).
Set the Job Start Time by entering Hour and Minute. In case of periodical frequency, enter the relevant periods. For weekly and monthly schedules, select Day of the Week or Day of the Month.
click Add.
If you want to edit a scheduled ⪪ job (for example, change its frequency, time, or date), select the job in the table and click Edit. Then change the desired parameters and click OK.
If you want to cancel a scheduled job and delete it from the table, select the job in the table and click Delete.
Click OK to apply the settings and quit the ⪪ Configuration, or continue with other configurations.
